welcome.title: Welcome to the Ecopia Value Chain (EVC) Platform
welcome.description1: The EVC platform is a digital infrastructure developed to address persistent bottlenecks in agricultural value chains, with a strong focus on the coffee sector in Ethiopia. These bottlenecks include scattered or missing production data, limited financial inclusion, costly and complicated certification processes, and weak market connections—especially for smallholder farmers, cooperatives, and rural entrepreneurs.
welcome.description2: To overcome these challenges, EVC provides an integrated software solution that digitizes all key aspects of the value chain—from individual farmer registration to harvest tracking, cooperative management, logistics, compliance, and market engagement. Our system is built to function offline in rural settings and does not require individual farmers to own smartphones. Instead, trained local youth—known as Data Logistic Managers (DLMs)—are deployed to collect data and support daily operations using tablets or shared devices.

eudrCompliance.title: EUDR Compliance: What Ethiopian Exporters Need to Know
eudrCompliance.subtitle: Breaking down the new EU Deforestation Regulation and its impact on coffee exports from Ethiopia.

introduction.title: Introduction
content: The European Union Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) represents one of the most significant regulatory changes affecting global agricultural trade in recent years. For Ethiopian coffee exporters, this regulation is not just another compliance hurdle—it's a fundamental shift that will determine market access to one of the world's largest coffee-consuming regions.
As the regulation comes into full effect, Ethiopian producers, cooperatives, and exporters must understand what EUDR means, why it matters, and how they can adapt to meet these new requirements.

whatIsEUDR.title: What is the EUDR?
content: The EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR) is a comprehensive law designed to ensure that products imported into the European Union do not contribute to deforestation or forest degradation anywhere in the world. The regulation covers seven key commodities: cattle, cocoa, coffee, palm oil, rubber, soy, and wood.
For coffee, this means that every shipment entering the EU must be accompanied by proof that the coffee was produced on land that was not deforested after December 31, 2020.
requirements: Products are deforestation-free (no deforestation after December 31, 2020)
Products are legally produced in accordance with the laws of the country of production
Complete traceability to the exact plot of land where the coffee was grown
whatIsEUDR.conclusion: This means that coffee farmers, cooperatives, and exporters in Ethiopia must show clear geolocation data (GPS mapping), harvest records, and proof of legal land use.

whyMatters.title: Why This Matters for Ethiopia
whyMatters.content: Ethiopia is one of the world's largest coffee producers, with coffee accounting for a significant portion of the country's export earnings. The EU is a major market for Ethiopian coffee, making EUDR compliance essential for maintaining these valuable trade relationships. Non-compliance could result in products being rejected at EU borders, leading to significant financial losses and damaged reputations.

items.title: Geolocation Data
items.content: Every coffee plot must be mapped with precise GPS coordinates. This includes smallholder farms, which make up the majority of Ethiopia's coffee production.

items.title: Legal Documentation
items.content: Proof that the land is legally owned or used, and that all applicable laws were followed during production.

items.title: Deforestation-Free Proof
items.content: Evidence that no deforestation occurred on the land after December 31, 2020, typically through satellite imagery or official documentation.

items.title: Supply Chain Traceability
items.content: Complete documentation of the coffee's journey from farm to export, including processing, storage, and transportation records.

items.title: Smallholder Fragmentation:
items.content: Most Ethiopian coffee comes from smallholder farmers with plots as small as 0.5 hectares, making individual mapping and documentation complex.

items.title: Limited Digital Infrastructure:
items.content: Many rural areas lack the digital tools and connectivity needed for comprehensive data collection and management.

items.title: Documentation Gaps:
items.content: Historical land use records and legal documentation may be incomplete or difficult to access.

items.title: Cost and Complexity:
items.content: The resources required for compliance can be overwhelming for smaller exporters and cooperatives.

items.title: Digital Traceability Solutions
items.content: Digital platforms can help track deforestation risks and provide the documentation needed for EUDR compliance through GPS mapping and supply chain tracking.

items.title: Cooperative Collaboration
items.content: Working through cooperatives can help smallholder farmers pool resources and share the costs of compliance documentation.

items.title: Government Support
items.content: The Ethiopian government can play a crucial role by providing legal documentation support and facilitating access to satellite imagery.

items.title: Capacity Building
items.content: Training programs for farmers, cooperatives, and exporters on EUDR requirements and compliance procedures.

items.title: Technology Adoption
items.content: Implementing digital tools for data collection, GPS mapping, and supply chain management.

conclusion.title: Conclusion
content: The EUDR represents both a challenge and an opportunity for Ethiopian coffee exporters. While compliance requires significant effort and investment, it also opens doors to premium markets that value sustainability and transparency.
Success will depend on collaboration between farmers, cooperatives, exporters, technology providers, and government agencies to build the systems and processes needed for compliance.

introduction.paragraph1: The Ecopia Value Chain (EVC) platform is not only a digital tool for managing agricultural operations—it's also designed to help producers, cooperatives, and buyers meet increasingly strict international compliance standards. We help users navigate both public regulations, like the EU Deforestation Regulation (EUDR), and private sustainability standards, including our own Ecopia Certification program.
introduction.paragraph2: Compliance is no longer optional—it is essential for reaching international markets, securing premium prices, and building lasting relationships with buyers. EVC simplifies this process with embedded tools that support data collection, traceability, documentation, and third-party verification.

whatIsEUDR.title: What is EUDR (EU Deforestation Regulation)?
whatIsEUDR.description: The EUDR is a regulation from the European Union aimed at stopping deforestation and forest degradation caused by the production and consumption of certain agricultural commodities— including coffee and cocoa. As of 2025, any company importing these goods into the EU must prove that their products:
requirements: Are traceable to their exact origin
whatIsEUDR.conclusion: This means that coffee farmers, cooperatives, and exporters in Ethiopia must show clear geolocation data (GPS mapping), harvest records, and proof of legal land use.

theTeam.title: Our Leadership Team
theTeam.subtitle: Meet the experienced leadership team behind Ecopia Value Chain, dedicated to transforming African agriculture through digital innovation and sustainable practices.

lemlem.description: has been Ecopia's accountant for over 10 years, bringing valuable experience from her time in Ethiopian government institutions. With her leadership, we began digitizing our documentation early on, aligning seamlessly with the government's digital transformation agenda. Today, all our records are digital and soon to be securely stored in the cloud. This shift has significantly improved efficiency, transparency, and accountability. At Ecopia, we believe digitalization is the most effective antidote to corruption in public institutions. By reducing manual handling and increasing traceability, it lays the foundation for a more honest, efficient, and future-ready Ethiopia.

felix.description: Having grown up in Ethiopia and Germany, born into a highly dynamic politically involved family, Felix was raised between AU summits in Addis Abeba and urgent foreign relations council meetings in Berlin. Already at an early age Felix demonstrated leadership skills and the ability to broker multi stakeholder partnerships between civil society, government and the private sector. Demonstrating long term strategic vision and a creative non conventional problem solving approach, making him our Chief Strategy Officer.

mitslal.description: With over 30 years of experience, working with governments, and international organizations, advising cabinet members in different countries of the African continent. Having successfully built several companies, and training more than 15000 farmers in manufacturing and brokering deals with large international companies, she has the experience and vision to lead this company to long-lasting success.

hayridi.description: is the pride of Ecopias Training and Operations Team. With his dedication, we launched farmer training programs focused on food, cosmetics, and herbal medicinal plants. Over the years, Hayrdi has trained and certified more than 4,000 farmers across 14 different sites. His exceptional ability to standardize formulations—developed by Dr. Mitslal Kifleyesus-Matschie and other experts—has enriched Ecopia's knowledge base with over 50 food recipes, 70 cosmetic formulations, and 150 medicinal plant-based products. His work continues to strengthen local knowledge, create economic opportunities, and promote high-quality, African-made natural products rooted in science and tradition.
